vulnerability_findings.name: arbitrary-send
vulnerability_findings.message:
FibonacciBalance.withdraw (patch_18.sol#17-23) sends eth to arbitrary user
	Dangerous calls:
	- msg.sender.transfer(calculatedFibNumber * 1000000000000000000) (patch_18.sol#22)

vulnerability_findings.name: controlled-delegatecall
vulnerability_findings.message:
FibonacciBalance.withdraw (patch_18.sol#17-23) uses delegatecall to a input-controlled function id
	(success) = fibonacciLibrary.delegatecall(fibSig,withdrawalCounter) (patch_18.sol#20)

vulnerability_findings.name: controlled-delegatecall
vulnerability_findings.message:
FibonacciBalance.fallback (patch_18.sol#25-28) uses delegatecall to a input-controlled function id
	(success) = fibonacciLibrary.delegatecall(msg.data) (patch_18.sol#26)

vulnerability_findings.name: uninitialized-state
vulnerability_findings.message:
FibonacciBalance.calculatedFibNumber (patch_18.sol#6) is never initialized. It is used in:
	- withdraw (patch_18.sol#17-23)

vulnerability_findings.name: constable-states
vulnerability_findings.message:
FibonacciBalance.calculatedFibNumber should be constant (patch_18.sol#6)
FibonacciBalance.start should be constant (patch_18.sol#8)

vulnerability_findings.name: external-function
vulnerability_findings.message: FibonacciBalance.withdraw (patch_18.sol#17-23) should be declared external

vulnerability_findings.name: external-function
vulnerability_findings.message: FibonacciLib.setStart (patch_18.sol#35-37) should be declared external

vulnerability_findings.name: external-function
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code:
function setFibonacci(uint n) public {
        calculatedFibNumber = fibonacci(n);
vulnerability_findings.message: FibonacciLib.setFibonacci (patch_18.sol#39-41) should be declared external

vulnerability_findings.name: low-level-calls
vulnerability_findings.message:
Low level call in FibonacciBalance.withdraw (patch_18.sol#17-23):
	-(success) = fibonacciLibrary.delegatecall(fibSig,withdrawalCounter) patch_18.sol#20

vulnerability_findings.name: low-level-calls
vulnerability_findings.message:
Low level call in FibonacciBalance.fallback (patch_18.sol#25-28):
	-(success) = fibonacciLibrary.delegatecall(msg.data) patch_18.sol#26

vulnerability_findings.name: naming-convention
vulnerability_findings.message: Parameter '_fibonacciLibrary' of FibonacciBalance. (patch_18.sol#13) is not in mixedCase

vulnerability_findings.name: naming-convention
vulnerability_findings.message: Constant 'FibonacciBalance.fibSig' (patch_18.sol#11) is not in UPPER_CASE_WITH_UNDERSCORES

vulnerability_findings.name: naming-convention
vulnerability_findings.message: Parameter '_start' of FibonacciLib.setStart (patch_18.sol#35) is not in mixedCase

vulnerability_findings.name: Delegatecall to user-supplied address (SWC 112)
vulnerability_findings.message:
The contract delegates execution to another contract with a user-supplied address.
The smart contract delegates execution to a user-supplied address.This could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code in the context of this contract account and manipulate the state of the contract account or execute actions on its behalf.
Classification: SWC-112

vulnerability_findings.name: Integer Arithmetic Bugs (SWC 101)
vulnerability_findings.message:
The arithmetic operator can overflow.
It is possible to cause an integer overflow or underflow in the arithmetic operation. 
Classification: SWC-101

vulnerability_findings.name: Integer Arithmetic Bugs (SWC 101)
vulnerability_findings.message:
The arithmetic operator can overflow.
It is possible to cause an integer overflow or underflow in the arithmetic operation. 
Classification: SWC-101

vulnerability_findings.name: Delegatecall to user-supplied address (SWC 112)
vulnerability_findings.message:
The contract delegates execution to another contract with a user-supplied address.
The smart contract delegates execution to a user-supplied address.This could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code in the context of this contract account and manipulate the state of the contract account or execute actions on its behalf.
Classification: SWC-112

vulnerability_findings.name: State access after external call (SWC 107)
vulnerability_findings.message:
Read of persistent state following external call
The contract account state is accessed after an external call to a user defined address. To prevent reentrancy issues, consider accessing the state only before the call, especially if the callee is untrusted. Alternatively, a reentrancy lock can be used to prevent untrusted callees from re-entering the contract in an intermediate state.
Classification: SWC-107

vulnerability_findings.name: Multiple Calls in a Single Transaction (SWC 113)
vulnerability_findings.message:
Multiple calls are executed in the same transaction.
This call is executed following another call within the same transaction. It is possible that the call never gets executed if a prior call fails permanently. This might be caused intentionally by a malicious callee. If possible, refactor the code such that each transaction only executes one external call or make sure that all callees can be trusted (i.e. they’re part of your own codebase).
Classification: SWC-113

vulnerability_findings.name: State access after external call (SWC 107)
vulnerability_findings.message:
Write to persistent state following external call
The contract account state is accessed after an external call to a user defined address. To prevent reentrancy issues, consider accessing the state only before the call, especially if the callee is untrusted. Alternatively, a reentrancy lock can be used to prevent untrusted callees from re-entering the contract in an intermediate state.
Classification: SWC-107
